journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Comparative investigation of tip leakage flow and its effect on stage performance in shrouded and unshrouded turbines

contrib-group.aff: College of Power and Energy Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, China

author-notes.corresp: Qun Zheng, College of Power and Energy Engineering, Harbin Engineering University, Harbin, China. Email: zhengqun@hrbeu.edu.cn

abstract.p: In order to provide reference for the choice of the turbine architecture in specific application, comparative investigation was conducted to investigate the shrouded and unshrouded rotor tip leakage flows by means of the commercial CFX software, which modeled the flow in a 1.5-stage turbine. Tip leakage loss production mechanisms as well as the effects of tip clearance and pitch–chord ratio on tip leakage and stage performances were discussed and compared in this article. Numerical results show that, the leakage flow at the shroud cavity inlet effectively removes the boundary layer at rotor leading edge, and then reduces the casing secondary flows inside rotor passage. There is a break-even tip clearance at which both the shrouded and unshrouded turbines have the same efficiency, and if tip clearance is less than it, the unshrouded turbine performs better than the shrouded turbine. Compared to the unshrouded turbine, the shrouded turbine can reduce the sensitivity of turbine performances to changes in tip clearance. Moreover, at the given relative change in leakage flow, the relative change in work is approximately twice the relative change in efficiency. Besides, pitch–chord ratio has the different impact on the tip leakage mixing processes in shrouded and unshrouded turbines. It is effective to achieve lower tip leakage losses by turning the leakage flows to reduce mixing losses in shrouded turbines, and by blade tip design or tip clearance treatment to reduce the tip leakage flow in unshrouded turbines.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Turbine blade tips have been, and continue to be one of major causes for loss of efficiency and loss of work in turbomachinery. The tip leakage losses occupy a large proportion in total losses of turbomachinery, which are considered in different ways depending on whether the blade is shrouded or unshrouded. Both shrouded and unshrouded turbines are commonly used in the gas turbine industry. Shrouded turbines are known to be aerodynamically more efficient than unshrouded turbines at the same flow conditions, because the tip leakage flows can be minimized by the use of multiple seals.1 The main benefit of using an unshrouded turbine rotor is that it reduces the turbine weight and the stress in the rotor blade root, compared to heavier shrouded rotors with higher number of blades. Hence the unshrouded turbine can run faster, which could increase the work output.2

Extensive works have been published on the tip leakage flows in unshrouded turbines. Studies in this area have continued from theoretical study,3,4 to cascade flow environments,5–8 and finally to full turbine test rigs.9–12 A very detailed overview of the tip leakage flows in unshrouded turbines can be found in the lecture series by Sjolander.13 Having understood the general physics of tip leakage flows, different strategies can be investigated to reduce the tip leakage flows and losses. In the past 50 years, various attempts to reduce the leakage flows and losses through blade tip modification have been tried. Most modifications fail to show considerable improvement,14 some show improvement but are too difficult to enter commercial service (added weight),15–17 and others have not been investigated enough to warrant their usage.18 However, some simple geometric modifications have seen widespread use, such as squealer tips,19,20 rounded edge tips21 and so on.

In recent years, industries have performed studies on shrouded blade tips. The physics of secondary path flows (shroud leakage, cavity and cooling flows), and their interactions with the main flow have been intensively investigated.1,22–29 Furthermore, a range of investigations is also dedicated to geometric modifications of shroud cavities and their consequences of the interaction between shroud leakage flows and main flows.30–34 These geometrical modifications directly aim at reducing mixing losses and subsequent row losses by influencing the velocity components of the shroud leakage flow.

Although shroud or tip leakage flows in shrouded and unshrouded turbines have been respectively investigated in detail, very little work has been published on the comparative investigation of the shrouded and unshrouded rotor tip leakage flow mechanisms, as well as the effect of tip clearance (including very small tip clearances) on stage performances at engine-representative conditions. In addition, in shrouded turbines, blade weight not only affects the blade root stresses, but can also have serious effects on the blade aerodynamic design, changing the reaction and work of the turbine stage, due to the fact that most blade tip designs seek to reduce the blade root stresses through higher number of blades. Besides, the number of blades (or pitch–chord ratio) has an important effect on the unshrouded rotor tip leakage flow rate as shown in Denton’s work.1 Nonetheless, very little information is available regarding the effect of pitch–chord ratio on shrouded and unshrouded turbines. Harvey and Ramsden35 compared the tip leakage loss at pitch–chord ratios of 1.14 and 0.57. For the given inlet and exit angles, the tip leakage loss is significantly reduced by at least 44%. However, the equation for the tip leakage loss coefficient from Denton1 predicts that reducing the pitch–chord ratio should increase the tip leakage loss.

The numerical investigation presented in this article made a comparison of the shrouded and unshrouded rotor tip leakage flows by means of the commercial CFX software, which modeled the flow in a 1.5-stage turbine. Based on the analytic models for the shrouded and unshrouded rotor tip leakage flows presented by Denton,1 the mechanisms for the formation of the tip leakage over shrouded and unshrouded rotor blades as well as the effects of tip clearance and pitch–chord ratio on tip leakage and stage performances were discussed and compared in this article.

sec.title: Turbine configuration
sec.p:
In order to provide reference for the choice of the turbine architecture in specific application, comparative investigation was carried out to investigate the tip leakage flows in shrouded and unshrouded turbines. As shown in Figure 1, the necessary space between the unshrouded rotor and the stationary casing is referred to as the tip clearance, while the tip clearance in shrouded rotors is formed between the shroud outer surface and the casing. Flow through the tip gap is termed the tip leakage flow. In order to make a fair comparison between the shrouded and unshrouded turbines, all the cases have the same outer casing diameter, and the cases with the same tip clearance have the same rotor blade height. Figure 1.
Shrouded and unshrouded rotor configurations.

The blade geometry chosen for this investigation is taken from the first three blade rows of the two-stage high pressure turbines in GE-E3 engines as shown in Figure 2. The rotor blades are twisted, and have a constant axial chord length of 28.7 mm and an aspect ratio (span to chord) of 1.39. Main design parameters are shown in Table 1. The numerical investigations have been carried out for seven tip clearances from 0.7% to 4.7% of blade span, and for four pitch–chord ratios from 0.62 to 1.09. Figure 2.
Computational domain and grid details of shrouded and unshrouded turbines.
Table 1.
Main design parameters.
Parameters Values
Turbine mass flowrate, mM (kg/s) 24.28
Absolute pressure ratio, π 0.41
Max power, N (kW) 6257.77
Inlet Mach number, Ma 0.11
Blade number (stator/rotor/stator), g 46/76/48
Rotor blade height, h (mm) 42.7
Rotor true chord, c (mm) 35.2
Rotor outer diameter, d (mm) 732

sec.title: Numerical technique
sec.p: The numerical investigation presented in this article was performed by using commercial software called CFX5.7.36 The solutions were obtained by solving the compressible Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes equations using a finite volume technique with a second-order upwind discretization scheme. A standard k-omega two-equation model developed by Menter37 is used in this investigation for turbulence closure, and automatic wall treatment is applied, which shifts gradually between a low-Reynolds number approach and wall functions based on the grid densities.

The computational domain can be seen in Figure 2, which takes into account a single-blade passage with periodic boundary conditions imposed along the circumferential direction. Also, the shroud labyrinth seals are simulated on a reduced domain, which has the equal pitch as the single rotor blade passage. The inlet and exit of the computational domain are situated one and two axial chord lengths of the rotor blade row upstream and downstream of the blade, respectively. Absolute total temperature and absolute total pressure are specified at the flow path inlet along with the inlet flow angle. Average static pressure is specified at the exit to the flow path,38 and the pressure profile on the exit is obtained from the interior field through extrapolation. Here, the average constraint is applied by comparing the area-weighted pressure average over the entire outlet to the specified value, and the pressure profile at the outlet is shifted by this difference such that the new area-weighted pressure average will be equal to the specified value.36 Solid surfaces are assumed to be adiabatic, and the no-slip condition is applied. In all calculations the identical boundary conditions were used. Detailed blade geometry and operating conditions can be found in the NASA report.39

Structured hexahedral grids are used for both the shroud cavity and the main passage. Shroud cavity and main passage grids are first generated separately, and then they are assembled with the help of interfaces. Figure 2 shows the computational grids of shrouded and unshrouded turbines. The grid of the shroud cavity is created with meshing package ANSYS ICEM CFD, while stator and rotor domains are meshed by Autogrid5 (pre-processor to NUMECA). The main channel domain was discretized into H-type grids, while the regions around blade surface and tip gap were discretized into O-type grids to improve grid quality. Furthermore, the grid was clustered near the leading edge, trailing edge and near tip region, with 33 spanwise grid points in the gap. The y+ (of the closest grid point from wall) is around 2 in the blade and endwall surfaces.

Anker et al.40,41 made a comparison of unsteady and steady simulations about the interactions of the leakage flow and the main flow in the shrouded turbine. The results have shown that it is perfectly sufficient to conduct steady-state simulations in order to capture the average rotor leakage flow effects. Therefore, the discussion in this investigation is limited to the results obtained from steady-state simulations. Based on the consideration of steady-state calculations, ‘Stage’ interface (mixing plane approach) was used;33,42,43 here, the circumferentially average flow information is transferred from the upstream side of the interface to the downstream side, that is, meridional variation of the flow is maintained across the interface. However, the stage averaging at the interface incurs a one-time mixing loss, and this loss is equivalent to assuming that the physical mixing supplied by the relative motion between stator and rotor domains is sufficiently large to cause any upstream velocity profile to mix out prior to entering the downstream blade row.36 In spite of the inherent limitations of this interface, acceptable agreement between measured and predicted data can still be realized.33,43 In the work of Gier et al.24 and Mahle,29 ‘Frozen Rotor’ interfaces were used to connect the shroud cavity and the main passage. They also compared the numerical simulation with experimental data, and obtained a pretty reasonable computation quality. Besides, in the present investigation, the shroud seal structure is circumferentially symmetrical, and the shroud cavity is modeled in the same frame of reference as the rotor blade row. On balance, ‘Frozen Rotor’ interface36,44 was adopted to interpolate the aerodynamic data between the shroud cavity and the main passage.

All the cases presented in this article are converged to residual levels of the order of 10−5, and have been converged to less than 0.1% mass flow error between the inlet and exit of the computational domain. Nearly, 200 iterations are required for convergence. To check the grid sensitivity, the shrouded and unshrouded turbines are calculated respectively by CFX5.7 with five different grid densities, which are approximately chosen from 0.95 × 106 to 1.9 × 106 grid nodes per blade pitch. The results show that the leakage flow rate keeps constant until the number of grid nodes is up to 1.7 × 106 for shrouded turbines and 1.37 × 106 for unshrouded turbines. Therefore, the numerical calculations were performed with 1.7 × 106 grid nodes for shrouded turbines and 1.37 × 106 grid nodes for unshrouded turbines in this article.

sec.title: Tip leakage loss generation
sec.p: Concerning the tip leakage theoretical models, studies by Denton1 draw most attention. For shrouded turbines, Denton considers shroud leakage flow approximated as isentropic under the assumption of a single sealed blade and incompressible flow, and assumes that the mixing takes place at the exit from the labyrinth seals. Therefore, the shroud leakage loss coefficient can be approximated by (1)ξshrouded=2mLmM [1-Wu,LWu,2sin2β2 ]

For unshrouded turbines, Denton considers tip leakage flow as a jet driven by the pressure difference across a blade tip, with mixing loss being body of tip leakage loss. Therefore, Denton neglects the mixing inside the tip gap and assumes that the mixing takes places at the blade suction side. From this approach, the tip leakage loss coefficient can be approximated by (2)ξunshrouded=2Cdτhcs1cosβ2∫0 1 (WsW2 )3 (1-WpWs ) ×1- (WpWs )2dzc

In the derivation of these equations, some simplifications are done, so the absolute values should not be fully trusted before any experiment correction is made, but the trends should be more trustworthy.45 It can be concluded from Denton’s equations (1) and (2) that the shroud or tip leakage loss coefficient depends on the leakage mass fraction and therefore to the tip clearance. It is also observed that the leakage loss coefficient increases with a larger mismatch of both velocity components of the leakage flow and the main flow. This is the pressure side to suction side velocity mismatch for unshrouded turbines and the change in swirl velocity across the rotor blade row for shrouded turbines. It is particularly worth noting that for both shrouded and unshrouded turbines the leakage mass fraction depends on the clearance–span ratio (τ/h), but in unshrouded turbines there is also a chord–pitch ratio (c/s) factor.
In the following section, tip leakage loss production mechanisms, and the effects of tip clearance and pitch–chord ratio on shrouded and unshrouded turbines will be discussed and compared in detail.

sec.title: Tip leakage loss production mechanisms
sec.p:
The flow patterns over the shrouded turbine rotor with a single shroud seal and unshrouded turbine blade are shown in Figures 3 and 4, respectively. Unlike the unshrouded rotor tip leakage flow driven by the pressure difference between the pressure and suction surfaces at the tip, the shrouded rotor shroud leakage flow is driven by the pressure difference between the upstream and downstream pressures at tip (Figures 3(a), 3(b) and 4(a)), leading to the different tip leakage mixing processes. These affects the losses per unit leakage flow, which mainly depends on the velocity difference of the main flow and the leakage flow as can be seen in Figures 3(c) and 4(b), whilst the flow processes over the shroud or the gap mainly affect the leakage flow rate. Furthermore, much of the mixing take places downstream of the rotor blade for shrouded turbines but near the suction surface of the rotor blade for unshrouded turbines. This also has the different impact on the loss development inside the rotor passages. Figure 3.
Shrouded rotor tip leakage flow mechanisms.
Figure 4.
Unshrouded rotor tip leakage flow mechanisms.

The loss development inside shrouded and unshrouded rotor passages is shown in Figure 5. At rotor inlet, the casing boundary layer thickness is almost the same in both the shrouded and unshrouded turbines. At the shroud inlet cavity, the incoming boundary layer is sucked away due to the presence of shroud cavities, such that there is a significantly reduction of casing wall boundary layer thickness at the shrouded rotor leading edge (Figure 5(a)). Although, with a shroud at the blade tip the main flow is separated from the tip leakage flow, and then the tip passage vortex development is not longer suppressed by the tip leakage vortex inside rotor passage, overall, less secondary losses are generated as can be seen in the trailing edge section of Figure 5. At rotor outlet, for shrouded turbines, shroud leakage flows are re-injected into the main flow with the different velocity components of main flows and leakage flows, generating mixing losses. However, for unshrouded turbines, the leakage vortex diffuses and dissipates rapidly at the rotor outlet. Moreover, unlike the leakage flow over unshrouded blades, the shroud leakage flow does not form a vortex structure on the re-entry to the rotor passage, but a mixing zone. Figure 5.
Entropy function contours inside shrouded and unshrouded rotor passages.

sec.title: Effect of tip clearance on shrouded and unshrouded turbine aerodynamics
sec.p:
The effects of tip clearance on shrouded and unshrouded turbine aerodynamics are shown in Figure 6. In Figure 6(a), the shrouded turbine has a higher efficiency than the unshrouded turbine when the tip clearance is not very small. At the tip clearance of 0.62% of rotor blade span, both shrouded and unshrouded turbines have the same efficiency. When the tip clearance is further reduced, the unshrouded turbine performs better than the shrouded turbine, which can be supported by the experimental investigation of Yoon et al.46 That is because mixing in the cavities upstream and downstream of the shroud increases the losses at very small tip clearances. Besides, the efficiency decreases almost linearly with the tip clearance in the unshrouded turbines. However, it is not in the shrouded turbines when the tip clearance is very large. That is because when the tip clearance approaches the size of the casing-shroud gap at shroud cavity exit (Figure 1(a)), the gap itself behaves like an extra seal. The similar trend can be seen in Figure 6(b) where stage loading coefficient is defined as the ratio of the stagnation enthalpy change through a stage to the square of the blade speed. Figure 6.
Effect of tip clearance on shrouded and unshrouded turbine performances.

In order to quantify the effects of tip clearance on shrouded and unshrouded turbine aerodynamics, the exchange rates are calculated using the linear-fit curves through the data in Figure 6 except the data where the tip clearance is very large. Table 2 shows the sensitivity of shrouded and unshrouded turbine performances to changes in tip clearance. It can be observed that the shrouded turbine has a smaller exchange rate than the unshrouded turbine, and the work exchange rate is much more than the efficiency exchange rate in both shrouded and unshrouded turbines, which is caused by the quite distinct processes of leakage and of entropy generation. The flow leaking over the blade tip undergoes no change in angular momentum, and thus it is not available for doing work. If the leakage did not suffer an increase in entropy, it could be concluded that 1% of leakage flow will cause 1% drop in work, and this loss of work will be an inviscid effect. However, in practice the leakage flow suffers a large entropy increase during its leakage path, and extra entropy is generated when the leakage flow mixes with the main flow. These entropy increases will lead to loss of efficiency and extra loss of work. A classical turbomachinery rule shows that 1% of leakage flow causes 1% drop in efficiency. Therefore, it can be concluded that 1% of leakage flow causes more than 1% drop in work. Also, a simple theoretical analysis is presented below (3)η=Lu/Li,T
(4)Ψ=mMLu
(5)Δη/η≈-ΔmL/mL=ΔmM/mM
(6)ΔΨΨ=(Ψ+ΔΨ)-ΨΨ=(mM+ΔmM)(η+Δη)LT *-mMηLT *mMηLT *=Δηη+ΔmMmM+ΔmMmM·Δηη≈2Δηη where Lu is actual specific work, and Li,T is ideal specific work. It is found that 1% of leakage flow causes not only 1% drop in efficiency, but also approximately 2% drop in work. Table 2.
Sensitivity of shrouded and unshrouded turbine performances to changes in tip clearance.
Turbine type Efficiency exchange rate Δη/Δτ/h Work exchange rate ΔΨ/Δτ/h
Shrouded 1.54 2.71
Unshrouded 1.79 3.44

Tip leakage losses are considered in different ways depending on whether the blade is shrouded or unshrouded.1 For shrouded turbines, the leakage losses can be divided into two parts: losses inside the labyrinth chamber and mixing losses caused by the re-entering leakage into the main flow; for unshrouded turbines, the losses arise from two parts: losses inside the tip gap and losses caused by the mixing when the leakage flow leaves the tip gap. The effects of tip clearance on tip leakage loss and its breakdown are shown in Figure 7. For shrouded turbines, the loss values were obtained by calculating the mass-averaged entropy loss coefficient,47 which equals (7) (T2ΔS0.5m2V1 2 )mix
Figure 7.
Effect of tip clearance on tip leakage loss and its breakdown of shrouded and unshrouded turbines.

For unshrouded turbines, the total loss value was obtained by calculating the difference between the exit mass-averaged entropy loss coefficients with and without tip clearance. Also, the loss inside the tip gap is calculated by the entropy loss coefficient based on entropy increase between suction side and pressure side at the tip region. As the tip clearance increases, each part of the shroud or tip leakage loss increases, and most of the leakage losses are due to the mixing. Moreover, the proportion of mixing losses in unshrouded turbines is much more than that in shrouded turbines. It can also be seen that, in shrouded turbines, losses inside the labyrinth chamber decreases when the tip clearance is large, although the tip leakage flow rate increases with the increasing tip clearance. That may be because mixing in the cavities upstream and downstream of the shroud is weakened when the tip clearance is large.

sec.title: Effect of pitch–chord ratio on tip leakage and stage efficiency
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the effect of pitch–chord ratio on shrouded and unshrouded rotor tip leakages, where the changes in pitch–chord ratio are obtained simply by changing the number of rotor blades. In Figure 8(a), stage reaction is defined as the ratio of static pressure drop over the rotor blade row to that over the turbine stage, and Zweifel load coefficient (Zw) is calculated using the following equation (8)Zw=2sczcos2β2 (Wm,1Wm,2tanβ1+tanβ2 ) where s is the profile pitch, cz is the axial chord length, β1 and β2 are the inlet and exit flow angles relative to axial direction, and Wm,1 and Wm,2 are the inlet and exit meridional velocities, respectively. As the pitch–chord ratio reduces, the stage reaction is increased, while the Zweifel load coefficient is reduced. Therefore as shown in Figure 8(b), for shrouded turbines, the total tip leakage flow rate is increased due to the increased driving force of leakage through the shroud seal. However, the tip leakage flow rate per blade pitch is reduced. That is because the leakage area per blade pitch is reduced significantly. For unshrouded turbines, the tip leakage flow rate per blade pitch is reduced due to the reduced driving force of leakage through the tip gap. However, the total tip leakage flow rate is increased caused by the increased leakage flow area in proportion to the number of rotor blades. Figure 8.
Effect of pitch–chord ratio on shrouded and unshrouded rotor tip leakage flow driving forces and leakage flow rates.

Furthermore, it should be noted that as the pitch–chord ratio reduces, the main passage becomes blocked, leading to the reduced turbine mass flow rate. Besides, the reduced pitch–chord ratio increases the wall friction losses. Although it also reduces the flow turning, which is expected to damp the intensity of the secondary flows, the total main passage losses are still increased due to the increased number of blades.

As shown in Figure 9(a), although the total leakage mass flow and the total main passage losses are increased as the pitch–chord ratio reduces, the stage efficiency is not reduced with the reducing pitch–chord ratio, but there is an optimal pitch–chord ratio at which the turbine has the best performance. Besides, the stage efficiency is reduced more rapidly in shrouded turbines than in unshrouded turbines when the pitch–chord ratio exceeds the design value. That is because most of the leakage losses are mixing losses, which depends not only on the tip leakage mass flow, but also on the magnitude of the velocity difference between the leakage flow and the main flow. That is the change in swirl velocity across the rotor blade row for shrouded turbines and the pressure side to suction side velocity difference for unshrouded turbines as shown in Figure 9(b). The velocity difference leads to mixing of the leakage flow and the main flow, which affects the losses per unit leakage flow. However, the pitch–chord ratio has the different impact on the tip leakage mixing processes in both shrouded and unshrouded turbines as shown in Figure 9(b). As the pitch–chord reduces, although the main flow direction has the same trend due to the reduced turbine mass flow, the changes of the leakage flow direction are opposite in both shrouded and unshrouded turbines. For this reason, the mixing of the leakage flow and the main flow is increased in shrouded turbines but slightly reduced in unshrouded turbines. Therefore, the turbine efficiency is lower in shrouded turbines than in unshrouded turbines when the pitch–chord ratio is small, although the leakage flow rate is lower in shrouded turbines than in unshrouded turbines. Figure 9.
Effect of pitch–chord ratio on stage efficiency and mixing process of the leakage flow and the main flow.

list-item.p: The tip leakage flow at the shroud cavity inlet effectively removes the boundary layer at rotor leading edge, and then reduces the casing secondary flows inside rotor passage. Unlike the leakage flow over unshrouded blades, the shroud leakage flow does not form a vortex structure on the re-entry to the rotor passage, but a mixing zone.

There is a break-even tip clearance at which both the shrouded and unshrouded turbines have the same efficiency, and if tip clearance is less than it, the unshrouded turbine performs better than the shrouded turbine. In addition, when the tip clearance approaches the size of the casing-shroud gap at shroud cavity exit, the gap itself behaves like an extra seal.

Compared to the unshrouded turbine, the shrouded turbine can reduce the sensitivity of turbine performances to changes in tip clearance. Besides, at the given relative change in leakage flow, the relative change in work is approximately twice the relative change in efficiency.

Pitch–chord ratio has the different impact on the tip leakage mixing processes in shrouded and unshrouded turbines due to the opposite change in the leakage flow direction, which affects the losses per unit leakage flow. It is effective to achieve lower tip leakage losses by turning the leakage flows to reduce mixing losses in shrouded turbines, and by blade tip design or tip clearance treatment to reduce the over tip leakage flow in unshrouded turbines.
Cavity structure upstream and downstream of the shroud should be optimized in order to reduce entropy generation not conducive to the reduction of leakage.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work has been supported by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (No. HEUCFZ1104).
